awd_titl_txt: BBSRC-NSF/BIO:   Synthetic Biology: Engineering an algal pyrenoid into higher plants to enhance yields
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to lay the foundations for significant increases in global crop yields by improving the efficiency of carbon uptake in a plant. The research plan involves transferring key components of pyrenoids found in algae, into a plant, Arabidopsis, in order to improve photosynthesis. Pyrenoids are sub-cellular microcompartments that are found in the chloroplast of several algae and are involved in carbon fixation. The project consists of three aims that are each targeted at engineering one of the key components of the pyrenoid into Arabidopsis, and one computational aim that develops a quantitative model of pyrenoid function to support the other three aims. These four aims synergize to produce a minimal, functional pyrenoid in Arabidopsis. The work contributes to meeting the 2050 global food demand with minimal ecological impacts. The project trains high school, undergraduate, graduate and post-doctoral scientists in each of two principal participating laboratories and launches them onto the next stages of their careers. The project team is engaging industry and philanthropic organizations to facilitate translation of advances to crops. The team is sharing their research with the general public through outreach talks to general audiences at venues such as science caf's, through social media such as Twitter, and by improving Wikipedia pages. 

As a key step towards enhancing crop yields, this project aims to enhance CO2 uptake of the model plant Arabidopsis by engineering it with a minimal synthetic CO2 uptake mechanism derived from components of the pyrenoid from green algae. The project consists of three aims, each targeted at engineering one of the key components of the pyrenoid into Arabidopsis. The research plan involves (a) reconstituting a pyrenoid matrix in higher plants, (b) placing the Rubisco matrix around thylakoids containing bicarbonate transporters and (c) placing the pyrenoidal carbonic anhydrase into the thylakoid lumen. Computational methods are used throughout the project to develop a quantitative model of pyrenoid function that would drive further investigations. To support the plant engineering efforts, the investigators perform targeted research in algae and in vitro. The project benefits from an outstanding international team with a strong track record of collaboration in advancing both basic knowledge of the pyrenoid and the ability to engineer algal components into higher plants.

This collaborative US/UK project is supported by the US National Science Foundation and the UKRI Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Abstract

Productivity in many crops is limited by CO2 availability and water use. Those limitations could be overcome by transferring a performance-enhancing Carbon Concentrating Mechanism (CCM) from green algae to higher plants. Toward this goal, this project yielded significant advances in the understanding of the function of algal CCMs and their engineering into plants. We used the model alga Chlamydomonas to study the pyrenoid, the organelle at the core of the algal CCM. We discovered the structural basis underlying the biogenesis of the matrix, one of the pyrenoid's three sub-compartments. We discovered key proteins with roles in the biogenesis of pyrenoid tubules, a second compartment that delivers CO2 to the pyrenoid. We discovered a mechanism explaining how proteins are targeted to the pyrenoid. We developed a predictive model of the pyrenoid-based algal CCM that guides engineering. By leveraging these advances, our collaborators on the project successfully engineered a pyrenoid-like structure in the model C3 plant Arabidopsis. The project contributed to the training of three graduate students, three postdocs, and two undergraduates.

 

Background

Alleviating food insecurity is a major challenge for the present century. Novel strategies are needed to increase crop productivity, as yields of several of our grain crops, including rice and wheat, are plateauing. One strategy is to try to overcome the inefficiencies of the enzyme responsible for >99% of the Planet?s assimilation of carbon dioxide (CO2) into organic matter, Rubisco. Rubisco is slow and most land plants require large amounts of the enzyme to support photosynthesis. Micro-algae have found ways to accelerate Rubisco activity whilst minimizing investments into the enzyme by operating a Carbon-Concentrating Mechanism (CCM). Algal CCMs use energy to concentrate CO2 and deliver it in close proximity to Rubisco, accelerating Rubisco's catalytic rate. Key to the process is the packaging of Rubisco alongside a carbonic anhydrase inside a micro-compartment, called a pyrenoid. However, key aspects of pyrenoid biogenesis remain uncharacterized and must be understood before a pyrenoid-based algal CCM can be engineered into crops to enhance yields.

 

Aims and objectives

This project had two main objectives: (1) advance the molecular understanding of the pyrenoid; (2) assemble a pyrenoid in a model land plant (this objective was pursued by our UK partner).

 

Key accomplishments

1. We developed a predictive computational model of the pyrenoid (Fei, Wilson, et al. 2022). Our model recapitulates known biology and guides engineering efforts.

2. We determined the structural basis for pyrenoid matrix biogenesis (He et al. 2020). We discovered that the pyrenoid matrix is formed as follows: the linker protein EPYC1 has five binding sites for Rubisco, each of which binds to a specific site on the Rubisco small subunit. These interactions cause EPYC1 and Rubisco to form a phase-separated condensate, which is the matrix. Binding is transient, allowing the Rubiscos to flow past each other while staying together in the condensate.

3. We discovered that a Rubisco-binding motif targets proteins to the pyrenoid and holds together the pyrenoid's three sub-compartments (Meyer et al. 2020). The motif is present on many pyrenoid-localized proteins and is necessary and sufficient for their targeting to the matrix.

4. We discovered key proteins that bring membrane traversions into the pyrenoid condensate (manuscript in revision). We identified two proteins that are necessary for pyrenoid tubule biogenesis in Chlamydomonas. When expressed in plants containing reconstituted pyrenoid matrix, these proteins cause membranes to traverse this matrix. This is a key step toward reconstituting a functional pyrenoid-based CCM in plants.

5. We discovered dozens of protein components of the pyrenoid tubules (manuscript in preparation). We performed mass spectrometry on purified tubules to identify novel tubule proteins. Mutants lacking these proteins show growth defects under conditions that require a pyrenoid for function, and these mutants show pyrenoid tubule and matrix morphology defects.

 

Impact

The CAPP project impacts the understanding of photosynthetic CO2 assimilation. The scientific community and biotechnology industry are now better informed to embark on re-engineering approaches to increase plant productivity. The project also had significant impacts on the career development of its participants. Nearly a dozen undergraduate, PhD and postdocs have received a wide training in plant integrative biology. The project also promoted a strong and ongoing collaboration with our UK academic partners in Edinburgh and York.
